sen.j: 久子内親王（ひさこないしんのう、生年不詳 - 貞観 (日本)18年6月18日 (旧暦)（876年7月12日））は、平安時代前期の皇族。
sen.e: Imperial Princess Hisako (date of birth unknown-July 12, 876) was a member of the imperial family in the first half of the Heian period.
Imperial Princess Hisako (date of birth unknown-July 12, 876) was a member of the imperial family during the first half of the Heian period.
Imperial Princess Hisako (year of birth unknown - July 16, 876) was a member of the Imperial Family during the first half of the Heian period.
sen.cmt: 用語統一グレゴリオ暦に変換

sen.j: 仁明天皇の皇女で、母は宮人の従五位高宗女王（従四位岡屋王の娘）。
sen.e: She was a princess of Emperor Ninmyo, and her mother was a Kyujin (court lady), Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank), Princess Takamune (daughter of Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank), Prince Okaya).
She was the princess of Emperor Ninmyo, and her mother was a Kyujin (court lady), Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank), Princess Takamune (daughter of Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank, - Prince Okaya).
She was the princess of Emperor Ninmyo, and her mother was a Kyujin (court lady), Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank), Princess Takamune (daughter of Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank), - Prince Okaya).
Ise Saigu (vestal virgin princess serving at Ise-jingu Shrine).
Ise Saigu (vestal virgin princess serving at Ise-jingu Shrine).
Ise Saigu (vestal virgin princess serving at Ise-jingu Shrine).

sen.j: 母・高宗女王は高市皇子（天武天皇皇子）の曾孫。
sen.e: Her mother, Princess Takamune was a great-grandchild of Prince Takechi (prince of Emperor Tenmu).
Her mother, Princess Takamune was the great-grandchild of Prince Takechi (prince of Emperor Tenmu).
Her mother, Princess Takamune was the great-grandchild of Prince Takechi (prince of Emperor Tenmu).

sen.j: 久子内親王は天長10年（833年）3月に父仁明天皇の斎宮に卜定された。
sen.e: Imperial Princess Hisako was designated as Saigu (Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Ise-jingu Shrine) of her father, Emperor Ninmyo by bokujo (to decide by fortunetelling) in March, 833.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Imperial Princess Hisako was designated as Saigu (Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Ise-jingu Shrine) for her father, Emperor Ninmyo by bokujo (decided by fortunetelling) in March, 833.

Imperial Princess Hisako was designated as Saigu (Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Ise-jingu Shrine) for her father, Emperor Ninmyo by bokujo (decided by fortunetelling) in March, 833.

sen.j: 承和 (日本)2年（835年）9月5日伊勢に群行した。
sen.e: On September 5, 835, she went to Ise for Gunko (three years of purification for Saigu at Nonomiya, and returning to Ise).
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: On September 5, 835, she went to Ise for Gunko (three years of purification for Saigu at Nonomiya) and then returned to Ise.
On October 4, 835, she went to Ise for Gunko (three years of purification for Saigu at Nonomiya) and then returned to Ise.

sen.j: そして仁明天皇の崩御を受けて嘉祥3年（850年）5月退下した。
sen.e: In May 850, she resigned after Emperor Ninmyo passed away.
In May 850, she resigned after Emperor Ninmyo passed away.
In June 850, she resigned after Emperor Ninmyo passed away.

sen.j: 清和天皇の治世末期の貞観18年（876年）6月18日に薨去した。
sen.e: She passed away in the end of the reign of Emperor Seiwa, on June 18, 876.
She passed away at the end of the reign of Emperor Seiwa, on June 18, 876.
She passed away at the end of the reign of Emperor Seiwa, on July 16, 876.
She was muhon (without a court rank).
She was muhon (without a court rank).
She was muhon (without a court rank).
